title: 108_s2790
content:
The "Bisti PRLA Dispute Resolution Act" allows for the withdrawal of coal preference right lease applications. The "Bisti PRLA Dispute Resolution Act" allows for the withdrawal of coal preference right lease applications, with the Secretary of the Interior issuing a certificate of bidding rights to holders who withdraw their applications, relinquishing all associated rights. This process occurs without further adjudication of coal. The relinquishment of rights associated with withdrawn coal preference lease applications is effective upon the issuance of a bidding rights certificate. This process occurs without further adjudication by the Secretary. SEC. 3. METHOD FOR DETERMINING FAIR MARKET VALUE. The fair market value of coal reserves for withdrawn lease applications will be determined by a panel established by the Secretary within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The panel will consist of 3 representatives appointed by the Secretary and the lease holder. The Secretary will appoint 3 representatives to a panel to determine the fair market value of a coal reserve. A mineral appraiser will assist the panel in this process, and supplemental information may be used. The panel must submit their determination to the Secretary within 75 days of being established. The panel, appointed by the Secretary, will determine the fair market value of a coal reserve within 75 days. SEC. 4. ISSUANCE OF PATENTS TO RELINQUISHED PREFERENCE RIGHT LEASE APPLICATIONS.

The Secretary must issue patents to the Navajo Nation for land, including mineral rights, within 120 days of withdrawing a coal preference right lease application. This is to fulfill the Navajo Nation's land selection rights and promote mineral development in northwest New Mexico. Additionally, a certificate of bidding rights will be issued based on fair market value.

SEC. 5. USE OF EXCHANGE BIDDING RIGHTS. The certificate of bidding rights issued under section 4(a)(2) allows for transferability and can be used as a monetary credit against payments for Federal coal leases. The payment obligations for Federal coal leases include production royalties and bonus payments to the Secretary. If a certificate of bidding rights is used as a credit, only 50% of the amount payable under the lease can be applied, with the remaining 50% to be paid in cash or cash equivalent. Payment obligations for Federal coal leases require holders of a certificate of bidding rights to pay 50% in cash or cash equivalent, with the remaining 50% credited and redistributed by the Secretary. 50% of the cash payment goes to the State where the lease is located, while the other 50% credited through bidding rights is subject to redistribution. Payment obligations for Federal coal leases require holders of a certificate of bidding rights to pay 50% in cash, with the remaining 50% credited and redistributed by the Secretary under section 35 of the Mineral Leasing Act. 50% of the cash payment goes to the State where the lease is located, while the other 50% credited through bidding rights is subject to redistribution to the Reclamation and Miscellaneous Receipts accounts in the Treasury.
